title: Quiz 8: Labour Complications
topicName: Unit Three Part One: Labour and Puerperium
description: Shoulder dystocia, cord prolapse, and other labour complications

questions.question: What is the definition of shoulder dystocia?

options.text: Impaction of the fetal shoulders after delivery of the head
Umbilical cord wrapped around the fetal neck

questions.explanation: Shoulder dystocia is an obstetric emergency where the fetal anterior shoulder becomes impacted behind the maternal symphysis pubis after delivery of the head. It requires immediate maneuvers to release the shoulder.
questions.hint: This occurs after the baby's head is delivered but the shoulders get stuck.

questions.question: What is the HELPERR mnemonic used for?
questions.explanation: The HELPERR mnemonic is used for the systematic management of shoulder dystocia: H - Help, E - Episiotomy, L - Legs (McRoberts maneuver), P - Pressure (suprapubic), E - Enter maneuvers, R - Remove posterior arm, R - Roll patient.
questions.hint: This mnemonic guides the steps to manage shoulder dystocia.

questions.question: The McRoberts maneuver involves flexing the mother's thighs against her abdomen.
questions.explanation: True. The McRoberts maneuver is a key intervention for shoulder dystocia that involves sharply flexing the mother's thighs against her abdomen. This flattens the lumbar spine and increases the pelvic outlet.
questions.hint: This maneuver changes the angle of the pelvis.

questions.question: Which of the following are risk factors for shoulder dystocia? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Risk factors for shoulder dystocia include maternal diabetes, fetal macrosomia, prolonged second stage, and previous shoulder dystocia. Preterm delivery is not a risk factor as preterm infants are smaller.
questions.hint: Think about factors that result in larger babies or difficult deliveries.

questions.question: Match each HELPERR step with its description:
questions.explanation: H = Help (call for assistance), L = Legs (McRoberts maneuver), P = Pressure (suprapubic pressure), R = Remove (remove posterior arm). These are key maneuvers for shoulder dystocia.
questions.hint: Each letter represents a specific action to take.

questions.question: The definition of umbilical cord prolapse is when the cord presents ___BLANK___ the fetus.
questions.explanation: Umbilical cord prolapse is defined as the umbilical cord presenting before the fetus, usually after rupture of membranes. It is an obstetric emergency that requires immediate delivery to prevent fetal hypoxia.
questions.hint: The cord comes out before the baby.

questions.question: What is the immediate management for umbilical cord prolapse?

options.text: Relieve cord pressure and expedite delivery (usually cesarean)
Administer oxytocin to speed up labor

questions.explanation: Immediate management of umbilical cord prolapse includes relieving pressure on the cord (manually elevating the presenting part or placing the mother in knee-chest position) and expediting delivery, usually by emergency cesarean section.
questions.hint: The goal is to relieve pressure on the cord and deliver quickly.

questions.question: Which fetal presentation is associated with the highest risk of cord prolapse?
questions.explanation: Breech presentation is associated with the highest risk of cord prolapse because the fetal buttocks or feet do not fill the pelvic inlet as effectively as the head, allowing the cord to slip past.
questions.hint: This presentation doesn't fill the pelvic inlet well.

questions.question: Nuchal cord (umbilical cord wrapped around the neck) is always an emergency requiring immediate intervention.
questions.explanation: False. Nuchal cord is relatively common (occurring in about 25-30% of births) and is not always an emergency. It can often be managed by gently slipping the cord over the baby's head during delivery.
questions.hint: This is a relatively common finding that is often manageable.

questions.question: What is the primary maneuver to relieve pressure on a prolapsed cord while preparing for emergency delivery?
questions.explanation: The primary maneuver to relieve pressure on a prolapsed cord is manual elevation of the presenting part off the cord. The mother can also be placed in knee-chest or Trendelenburg position to reduce pressure.
questions.hint: This involves lifting the baby off the cord with your hand.
